unnormalised: Big news for job seekers! The Govt. of India just announced the release of a consolidated "Single ID" for students and employees. Heard about it? It's kinda interesting, actually.
normalised: Big news for job seekers! The Government of India just announced the release of a consolidated "Single I-D" for students and employees. Heard about it? It's kinda interesting, actually.

unnormalised: So, basically, think of it like this: instead of having to remember your Roll No. from college, your Employee ID from your first job, your PAN card for tax stuff, and everything else, you'll have one single, unique identifier. I know, right? Sounds like something out of a sci-fi movie!
normalised: So, basically, think of it like this: instead of having to remember your Roll Number from college, your Employee I-D from your first job, your P-A-N card for tax stuff, and everything else, you'll have one single, unique identifier. I know, right? Sounds like something out of a sci-fi movie!

unnormalised: Apparently, this "Single ID" will be linked to your Aadhaar No. (that's your 12-digit UIDAI thing, remember?). And from what I understand, it will then connect to all your educational records - like your marksheet serial numbers, your degree certificate numbers, and even your attendance records from back in school! It's wild.
normalised: Apparently, this "Single I-D" will be linked to your Aadhaar Number (that's your twelve-digit U-I-D-A-I thing, remember?). And from what I understand, it will then connect to all your educational records - like your marksheet serial numbers, your degree certificate numbers, and even your attendance records from back in school! It's wild.

unnormalised: For employment, it'll link your PF No. (Provident Fund number, for those who aren't familiar) and your UAN (Universal Account Number) as well as other professional certifications and skills. Imagine how much easier it'll be for companies to verify your credentials! No more calling up your old college to confirm your degree's legitimacy, hopefully.
normalised: For employment, it'll link your P-F Number (Provident Fund number, for those who aren't familiar) and your U-A-N (Universal Account Number) as well as other professional certifications and skills. Imagine how much easier it'll be for companies to verify your credentials! No more calling up your old college to confirm your degree's legitimacy, hopefully.

unnormalised: The Education Ministry stated this will streamline the application process for jobs and further studies. For instance, you won't have to manually fill in all your details every single time. The system will automatically pull the relevant data from your "Single ID" profile. Smart, huh?
normalised: The Education Ministry stated this will streamline the application process for jobs and further studies. For instance, you won't have to manually fill in all your details every single time. The system will automatically pull the relevant data from your "Single I-D" profile. Smart, huh?

unnormalised: Some folks are concerned about data privacy, of course. Which is fair! But the ministry is assuring everyone that strict data protection measures will be in place. They're saying that access to your data will be controlled and that you'll have the right to review and correct any inaccuracies. Let’s hope that’s the case.
normalised: Some folks are concerned about data privacy, of course. Which is fair! But the ministry is assuring everyone that strict data protection measures will be in place. They're saying that access to your data will be controlled and that you'll have the right to review and correct any inaccuracies. Let's hope that's the case.

unnormalised: Honestly, if it works as intended, it could be a real game-changer for both students and employees. Imagine – no more scrambling to find your 10th-grade registration number (you know, that long string of digits that starts with "ABCD/20XX/…") every time you fill out a form. Fingers crossed it's implemented well!
